raw_affiliation_strings: Qing Li is a Ph.D. candidate in the Educational Psychology Department in the Neag School of Education at the University of Connecticut. She earned her first doctoral degree in mechanical engineering. She then became an engineering faculty and published close to 30 technical papers in mechanical engineering journals. After many years of teaching experience in engineering schools, she developed a strong interest in learning psychology, in particular in the area of engineering education. She resigned as an associate professor from the School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, and started her Ph.D. study in Educational Psychology in 2006.
University of Connecticut

affiliations.raw_affiliation_string: Qing Li is a Ph.D. candidate in the Educational Psychology Department in the Neag School of Education at the University of Connecticut. She earned her first doctoral degree in mechanical engineering. She then became an engineering faculty and published close to 30 technical papers in mechanical engineering journals. After many years of teaching experience in engineering schools, she developed a strong interest in learning psychology, in particular in the area of engineering education. She resigned as an associate professor from the School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, and started her Ph.D. study in Educational Psychology in 2006.
University of Connecticut

raw_affiliation_strings: Hariharan Swaminathan is a professor and head of the Department of Educational Psychology at the University of Connecticut. Professor Swaminathan is internationally recognized for his expertise in educational measurement, and in particular, in the area of item response theory, and is the co-author of two books on item response theory. Professor Swaminathan's research interests are in the areas of Bayesian statistics, psychometrics, item response theory, multivariate analysis structural equation modeling, and hierarchical models. He serves on the editorial boards for the Journal of Educational Measurement, Applied Psychological Measurement, and Educational and Psychological Measurement. He has received the Outstanding Teacher Award from the University of Massachusetts, and is the recipient of the American Psychological Association's J. Cohen award for Distinguished Teaching and Mentoring.
University of Connecticut

affiliations.raw_affiliation_string: University of Connecticut

Hariharan Swaminathan is a professor and head of the Department of Educational Psychology at the University of Connecticut. Professor Swaminathan is internationally recognized for his expertise in educational measurement, and in particular, in the area of item response theory, and is the co-author of two books on item response theory. Professor Swaminathan's research interests are in the areas of Bayesian statistics, psychometrics, item response theory, multivariate analysis structural equation modeling, and hierarchical models. He serves on the editorial boards for the Journal of Educational Measurement, Applied Psychological Measurement, and Educational and Psychological Measurement. He has received the Outstanding Teacher Award from the University of Massachusetts, and is the recipient of the American Psychological Association's J. Cohen award for Distinguished Teaching and Mentoring.

raw_affiliation_strings: Jiong Tang is an associate professor in Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Connecticut. His current research and teaching interests are structural dynamics and system dynamics, sensing and signal processing, and controls. He earned a Ph.D. degree in Mechanical Engineering from Pennsylvania State University in 2001. Prior to joining the University of Connecticut in 2002, Dr. Tang worked in General Electric Global Research Center as a research engineer.
University of Connecticut

affiliations.raw_affiliation_string: University of Connecticut
